text: Tareq Amin This is a promising initiative. One sector that should not be overlooked by Humain Academy is universities. As the largest “pre-job-market prep programs,” they play a key role in shaping future talent. However, university program curricula are often disconnected from labor market needs, and adapting to rapid digital change is slow., as many faculty still see AI as a threat rather than an enabling tool. To drive meaningful change, AI training for universities must redefine their role in preparing graduates for today’s and tomorrow’s job market. Two guiding values are key: First, alignment, using curriculum mapping to link courses to any pre-defined national qualification frameworks and employer-demanded skills. Second: integration, embedding AI across all courses across programs, not just electives. This approach produces more competitive programs and curricula that remain relevant. For faculty, buy-in comes from practical, immediate value. AI should be framed as a practical, empowering tool that saves time and boosts productivity in tasks like: course design, grading, research support, content creation, etc. I believe universities are a key sector for creating a large-scale impact with AI training.

text: That’s a great idea Tareq Amin, and its impact will depend on execution. From my experience across entertainment, media, and marketplaces, working with both fresh graduates and seasoned professionals, I can offer few thoughts. - The traditional path of long academic study followed by years of hands-on work isn’t scalable for AI. It leaves many professionals unprepared for complex challenges and limits cross-industry innovation, whether in drug discovery, gaming, or personalized commerce. - Universities and online platforms already cover AI fundamentals. What’s urgently needed is applied AI education, how to use emerging models and tools in real-world contexts to drive second-order innovation. - This calls for modern curricula and teaching methods that produce immediately deployable skills, supported by local and international partnerships between industry and academia. Experts, students, and researchers should collaborate to build courses that address real use cases. - Finally, we need learning tracks tailored to different levels of AI literacy. Some theory is important, but the emphasis must be on practical, applied skills that empower more people to put AI to work.
